title: It’s finally time—Virgin Galactic is flying private astronauts into space
summary: It must be a magical moment to float freely above the world.

title: Viasat not ready to declare Viasat-3 Americas a total loss
summary: Viasat is holding off on a contingency plan for ViaSat-3 Americas in the hope it could still get some capacity from the broadband satellite despite its defective antenna, the operator’s chair and CEO Mark Dankberg said Aug. 9.

title: Japan’s Interstellar aims for orbital launch in 2025
summary: Japanese launch startup Interstellar Technologies is preparing for a static fire test later this year that could pave the way for orbital launch of its Zero rocket in 2025.

title: U.S. intelligence agencies take steps to protect commercial satellites
summary: The National Reconnaissance Office, the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency and U.S. Space Command last month signed an agreement to improve threat intelligence sharing with commercial satellite operators.

title: Viasat revenue grows as investigation continues into malfunctioning $750 million satellite
summary: Viasat reported a jump in quarterly revenue Wednesday, as the company continues to investigate its recent satellite malfunction and explores options to make up for some of the service it expected to add this year.

title: Lynk Global starts initial direct-to-device services in the Cook Islands
summary: Small satellite operator Lynk Global has started initial direct-to-device services in a small part of the Cook Islands in its second commercial launch with a local telco.

title: ESA confirms Ariane 6 debut to slip to 2024
summary: ESA acknowledged Aug. 8 what most of the space industry had long expected: the first flight of the Ariane 6 will not happen this year.

title: Artemis II astronauts get their first look at their Orion spacecraft
summary: The Artemis II astronauts that will be the first crew to fly around the Moon in 50 years got a peek at...

title: Vyoma Orders First Debris Monitoring Satellites For New Constellation
summary: Vyoma, a pioneering German startup focused on space debris monitoring, has entered into a strategic partnership with Bulgarian cubesat specialist EnduroSat to develop a constellation of pilot satellites aimed at tracking and cataloging space debris in low Earth orbit (LEO).

title: Dish Network plots two-way fixed broadband services in Ku-band
summary: Dish Network is seeking permission to use 12 GHz spectrum for fixed terrestrial broadband in the United States, three months after regulators rejected plans for mobile services in the band following interference concerns from Starlink and other satellite operators.
